facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 90 of 1965 filed by Dr. S. Dutt.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 90 of 1965. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated Februa

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated February 12, 1965 of Allahabad High Court in Criminal Revision No. 260 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 12, 1965 of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Revision No. 260 of 1963. S. R. Chari, A. N. Sinha and A. K. Nag, for the appella

facts.text: Dr. S. Dutt examined as expert witness by defence in Sessions Trial No. 60 of 1957 State v. Matadin and Ors. in Court of Additional Sessions Judge, Hardoi.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. S. Dutt who appeals to this Court by special leave against the judgment and order of Mr. Justice Misra of the Allahabad High Court  Lucknow Bench  dated February 12, 1965 was examined as an expert witness by the defence in a Sessions trial  State v. Matadin and Ors.-S.T. No. 60 of 1957  in the Court of Additional Sessions Judge, Hardoi.

facts.text: Dr. Dutt claimed diploma from Imperial College of Science and Technology, London specializing in criminology.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Dutt claimed to hold a diploma from the Imperial College of Science and Technology, London to the effect that he had specialised in the subject of criminology. He was cross-examined inter alia about this claim by the District Government counsel who was assisted by one Mr. Shyam Narain, Deputy Superintendent, Police  C.I.D.  Lucknow.

facts.text: Cross-examined by District Government counsel assisted by Mr. Shyam Narain, DSP Police C.I.D. Lucknow.

anchor.surface_text: He was cross-examined inter alia about this claim by the District Government counsel who was assisted by one Mr. Shyam Narain, Deputy Superintendent, Police  C.I.D.  Lucknow. Mr. Shyam Narain earlier had deposed himself as an expert witness for the prosecution.

facts.text: Mr. Shyam Narain deposed as expert witness for prosecution.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Shyam Narain earlier had deposed himself as an expert witness for the prosecution. Dr. Dutts testimony ran counter to the testimony of Mr. Shyam Narain and the credentials of Dr. Dutt were challenged.

facts.text: Dr. Dutt's testimony contrary to Mr. Shyam Narain's testimony; credentials challenged.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Dutts testimony ran counter to the testimony of Mr. Shyam Narain and the credentials of Dr. Dutt were challenged. The Judge asked Dr. Dutt to produce all his academic diplomas and certificates for his inspection.

facts.text: Sessions Judge asked Dr. Dutt to produce academic diplomas and certificates.

anchor.surface_text: The Judge asked Dr. Dutt to produce all his academic diplomas and certifi- cates for his inspection. Dr. Dutt produced the aforesaid diploma and it was taken on file as Ex. P-71 together with a statement which was marked Ex. P-72.

facts.text: Dr. Dutt produced diploma marked Ex. P-71 and statement Ex. P-72.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Dutt produced the aforesaid diploma and it was taken on file as Ex. P-71 to-ether with a statement which was marked Ex. P-72. The Sessions Judge pronounced judgment on October 29, 1957 acquitting Matadin and the other accused.

facts.text: Sessions Judge acquitted Matadin and others on October 29, 1957; passed strictures on prosecution; rejected Shyam Narain's evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The Sessions Judge pronounced judgment on October 29, 1957 acquitting Matadin and the other accused. He passed strictures on the prosecution and did not accept the evidence of Mr. Shyam Narain. Government did not appeal against the acquittal and that matter ended there.

facts.text: Government did not appeal against the acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: Government did not appeal against the acquittal and that matter ended there. On November 12, 1957 prosecution applied to the Session Judge under s. 195 of the Code of Criminal Procedure for the prosecution of Dr. Dutt under s. 193 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: On November 12, 1957, prosecution applied to Sessions Judge under s.195 CrPC for prosecution of Dr. Dutt under s.193 IPC; rejected same day.

anchor.surface_text: On November 12, 1957 prosecution applied to the Session Judge under s. 195 of the Code of Criminal Procedure for the prosecution of Dr. Dutt under s. 193 of the Indian Penal Code. It was stated in the application that the defence witness No. 3 Dr. S. Dutt has committed forgery of certain diploma produced in this Honble Court during the course of his evidence and he has used these forged documents as genuine. This application was rejected on November 12, 1957.

facts.text: Application stated Dr. Dutt committed forgery of diploma and used as genuine.

anchor.surface_text: It was stated in the application that the defence witness No. 3 Dr. S. Dutt has committed forgery of certain diploma produced in this Honble Court during the course of his evidence and he has used these forged documents as genuine. This application was rejected on November 12, 1957.

facts.text: Two days after rejection, Mr. Shyam Narain lodged report at Police Station Hardoi alleging Dr. Dutt offence under s.466/477 later 465/471 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: Two days later Mr. Shyam Narain lodged a report at Police Station, Hardoi alleging that Dr. Dutt had committed an offence under s. 466/477  subsequently changed to s. 465/471  of the Indian Penal Code in the Court of the Additional Sessions Judge, Hardoi while giving evidence in Sessions trial State v. Matadin and others.

facts.text: FIR stated diploma and statement forged and used as genuine with bad motive.

anchor.surface_text: The first information report stated that the diploma of the Imperial College of Science and Technology, London and the statement produced by Dr. Dutt were forged and that Dr. Dutt had used them in the court with a bad motive, passing them as genuine.

facts.text: On October 26, 1958, charge-sheet under s.465/471 IPC filed against Dr. Dutt in Court of Judicial Officer III, Hardoi by C.I.D. Police Lucknow.

anchor.surface_text: On October 26, 1958 a charge-sheet under s. 465/471, Indian Penal Code was filed against Dr. Dutt in the Court of the Judicial Officer III, Hardoi by the C.I.D. Police, Lucknow. The case went before the Additional District Magistrate  Judicial  Hardoi on transfer and at the commencement of the trial Dr. Dutt objected that he could not be legally prosecuted as the alleged facts disclosed an offence under s. 193, Indian Penal Code and a complaint in writing of the court was required under s. 195 of the Code of Criminal Procedure before cognizance could be taken.

facts.text: Case transferred to Additional District Magistrate (Judicial), Hardoi.

anchor.surface_text: The case went before the Additional District Magistrate  Judicial  Hardoi on transfer and at the commencement of the trial Dr. Dutt objected that he could not be legally prosecuted as the alleged facts disclosed an offence under s. 193, Indian Penal Code and a complaint in writing of the court was required under s. 195 of the Code of Criminal Procedure before cognizance could be taken.

facts.text: Dr. Dutt objected that offence under s.193 IPC, requires s.195 CrPC complaint; 465/471 not apply, evasion.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Dutt also contended that ss. 465/471 did not apply to the alleged facts and that the prosecution was attempting to evade the provisions of s. 195 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. During arguments on his petition Dr. Dutt also claimed that s. 196 and not s. 471 of the Indian Penal Code applied to the facts of the case and that even that offence required that the procedure of s. 195 should have been gone through.

facts.text: Prosecution contended offence under 465/471 for forgery and using forged document.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution, on the other hand, contended that Dr. Dutt was being prosecuted for forgery of the diploma and for using the said forged document and, therefore, the offence fell within ss. 465/ 471 of the Indian Penal Code. The Additional District Magistrate  Judicial  rejected the contentions of Dr. Dutt and held that there was no bar to the trial under s. 465/471, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Additional DM (J) rejected Dr. Dutt's contentions, held no bar to trial under 465/471.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional District Magistrate  Judicial  rejected the contentions of Dr. Dutt and held that there was no bar to the trial under s. 465/471, Indian Penal Code. Dr. Dutt filed revisions against the order in the Court of Sessions and in the High Court but without success.

facts.text: Dr. Dutt filed revisions to Sessions Court and High Court, unsuccessful; HC order February 12, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Dutt filed revisions against the order in the Court of Sessions and in the High Court but without success. The order of the High Court was pronounced on February 12, 1965 and the present appeal is against that order.

facts.text: Court held offence falls under ss.193/196 IPC, requires s.195 CrPC complaint; prosecution under 465/471 invalid.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the offence in the present case did not fall within ss. 465/471, I.P.C. and the prosecution launched against Dr. Dutt cannot be allowed to go on.

facts.text: Sessions Judge declined complaint under s.193 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: This application was rejected on November 12, 1957. Two days later Mr. Shyam Narain lodged a report at Police Station, Hardoi alleging that Dr. Dutt had committed an offence under s. 466/477  subsequently changed to s. 465/471  of the Indian Penal Code in the Court of the Additional Sessions Judge, Hardoi while giving evidence in Sessions trial State v. Matadin and others.

facts.text: Diploma produced by Dr. Dutt was forged and false document.

anchor.surface_text: The first information report stated that the diploma of the Imperial College of Science and Technology, London and the statement produced by Dr. Dutt were forged and that Dr. Dutt had used them in the court with a bad motive, passing them as genuine.

issues.text: Which of these two groups of sections (Chapter XVIII ss.465/471 or Chapter XI ss.193/196) applies here such that it determines whether the court had jurisdiction to take cognizance of the case without a complaint under s.195 CrPC

anchor.surface_text: Section 193 punishes the giving or fabricating of false evidence and section 196 punishes the using of evidence known to be false. Which of these two groups of sections applies here is the question on that depends whether the court had jurisdiction to take cognizance of the case.

issues.text: Whether the provisions of s.195 CrPC have been evaded by the prosecution by charging Dr. Dutt under ss.465/471 IPC instead of ss.193/196 IPC

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chari for Dr. Dutt first draws attention to certain observations of this Court in Basir-ul-Huq and Others v. The State of West Bengal and Nur-ul-Huda v. The State of West Bengal , where it is observed that s. 195 of the Code of Criminal Procedure must not be evaded if the bar created by it stands in the way of the prosecution.

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed; prosecution evaded s.195 by charging under 465/471 instead of 193/196

arguments.claim: Offence falls under Chapter XI ss.193/196 IPC (false evidence) not Chapter XVIII ss.465/471 (forgery); requires s.195 CrPC

anchor.surface_text: Section 193 punishes the giving or fabricating of false evidence and section 196 punishes the using of evidence known to be false. Which of these two groups of sections applies here is the question on that depends whether the court had jurisdiction...

arguments.claim: Dr. Dutt fabricated false evidence under s.192 IPC by making diploma with false statement intending it to appear in evidence causing erroneous opinion

anchor.surface_text: Section 192 then defines compendiously the offence of fabricating false evidence... Whoever causes any circumstance to exist or makes any document containing a false statement intending that such circumstance or false statement may appear in evidence...

arguments.claim: Dr. Dutt corruptly used evidence known to be false under s.196 IPC; 'corruptly' wider than fraudulently/dishonestly

arguments.claim: No offence under s.471 IPC as no dishonest intent (s.24); no wrongful gain/loss

anchor.surface_text: The word dishonestly is defined by s. 24 of Penal Code. A person who does anything with the intention of causing wrongful gain to one person or wrongful loss to another person, is said to do that thing dishonestly.

arguments.claim: Cannot evade s.195 by dropping serious charge (193/196) for lesser (465/471) bypassing court complaint

anchor.surface_text: It is not permissible for the prosecution to drop a serious charge and select one which does not require the procedure under s. 195... Such a device is not to be commended.

holdings.text: The offence in the present case did not fall within ss. 465/471, I.P.C. and the prosecution launched against Dr. Dutt cannot be allowed to go on.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the offence in the present case did not fall within ss. 465/471, I.P.C. and the prosecution launched against Dr. Dutt cannot be allowed to go on.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts involve fabrication and corrupt use of false document as evidence in judicial proceeding, falling under Chapter XI ss.193/196 IPC requiring s.195 CrPC complaint, not Chapter XVIII ss.465/471 lacking required dishonest/fraudulent intent.

holdings.text: The definition of the expression fabricating false evidence in s. 192 ... quite clearly covers this case.

anchor.surface_text: Section 192 then defines compendiously the offence of fabricating false evidence. The portion which Mr. Chari claims applies here may be set out Whoever causes any circumstance to exist or makes any docu

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dr. Dutt made document (diploma) containing false statement intending it to appear in evidence in judicial proceeding to cause erroneous opinion on material point (his expertise).

holdings.text: The action of Dr. Dutt was covered by ss. 192 and 196 of the Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: Section 196 next provides Whoever corruptly uses or attempts to use as true or genuine evidence any evidence which he knows to be false or fabricated shall be punished... The word corrupt does not necess

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dr. Dutt corruptly used known false/fabricated evidence (diploma); 'corruptly' wider than 'fraudulently/dishonestly', includes morally debased conduct per precedents.

holdings.text: Dr. Dutts conduct does not come within s. 471.

anchor.surface_text: It is a matter of some doubt whether he can be said to have used the diploma because he did not voluntarily bring the diploma to court. There is authority to show that such a user is not contemplated by s. 471

holdings.reasoning_summary: No dishonest intent (s.24: no wrongful gain/loss); produced under court order, not voluntary use; even if use, no fraudulent intent (s.25: no intent to induce disadvantageous action/omission).

holdings.text: The provisions of s.195 CrPC cannot be evaded by resorting to devices or camouflages; test is whether facts disclose primarily an offence requiring court complaint.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chari for Dr. Dutt first draws attention to certain observations of this Court in Basir-ul-Huq... Though, in our judgment, section 195 does not bar the trial of an accused person for a distinct off

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecution charged under lesser ss.465/471 to bypass s.195 requirement after Sessions Judge rejected complaint u/s.193; primary offence under ss.193/196.

holdings.text: It is not permissible for the prosecution to drop a serious charge and select one which does not require the procedure under s. 195 ... Such a device is not to be commended.

anchor.surface_text: It is not permissible for the prosecution to drop a serious charge and select one which does not require the procedure under s. 195 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. Such a device is not to be commended.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.196 (7 years) more serious than ss.465/471 (2 years); chosen to evade Sessions Judge's refusal of complaint u/s.193.

precedents.citation: Basir-ul-Huq and Others v. The State of West Bengal and Nur-ul-Huda v. The State of West Bengal 1 ... 1 1963 S.C.R. 836 at 842

anchor.surface_text: Basir-ul-Huq and Others v. The State of West Bengal and Nur-ul-Huda v. The State of West Bengal 1 , where it is observed that s. 195 of the Code of Criminal Procedure must number be evaded if the bar created by it stands in the way  1  1963 S.C.R. 836 at 842.

precedents.case_name: Basir-ul-Huq v. State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: Section 195 CrPC cannot be evaded by resorting to devices or camouflages; test is whether facts disclose primarily an offence requiring complaint of the court
precedents.cited_holding: Though, in our judgment, section 195 does number bar the trial of an accused person for a distinct offence disclosed by the same facts and which is number included within the ambit of that section, it has also to be borne in mind that the provisions of that section cannot be evaded by resorting to devices or camouflages.

precedents.citation: Emperor v. Rana Nana 1 ... I.L.R 46 Bom. 317

anchor.surface_text: In Emperor v. Rana Nana 1  Chief Justice Macleod companysidered the word to be of wider import than the words fraudulently or dishonestly and did number companyfine it to the taking, of bribes or cases of bribery. I.L.R 46 Bom. 317.

precedents.cited_proposition: "corruptly" is of wider import than "fraudulently" or "dishonestly" and not confined to taking of bribes

precedents.citation: Bibkhranjan Gupta v. The King,  2 ... I.L.R. 1949 2 Cal. 440

anchor.surface_text: In Bibkhranjan Gupta v. The King,  2  Mr. Justice Sen dealt at length with this word. He was companytrasting s. 196 with s. 471 and observed that the word companyruptly was number synonymous with dishonestly or fraudulently but was much wider. ... 2  I.L.R. 1949 2 Cal. 440.

precedents.cited_proposition: "corruptly" wider than "dishonestly" or "fraudulently", includes blameworthy or improper conduct even if not fraudulent or dishonest

precedents.citation: Assistant Sessions Judge North Arcot v. Ranaminal 1 ... LI-R. 36 Mad. 387

anchor.surface_text: There is authority to show that such a user is number companytemplated by s. 471 of the Indian Penal Code See Assistant Sessions Judge North Arcot v. Ranaminal 1  and Ma Ain Lon v. Ma On Nu  2 . LI-R. 36 Mad. 387.

precedents.case_name: Assistant Sessions Judge North Arcot v. Ranaminal
precedents.cited_proposition: Production of document on court order does not amount to 'using as genuine' under s.471 IPC

precedents.citation: Ma Ain Lon v. Ma On Nu  2 ... A.I.R.1925 Rangoon 191

anchor.surface_text: See Assistant Sessions Judge North Arcot v. Ranaminal 1  and Ma Ain Lon v. Ma On Nu  2 . Even if one were to hold that he did use the document as genuine his intention in producing it was to support his statement and number to cause a wrongful gain to himself or to cause a wrongful loss to another. A.I.R.1925 Rangoon 191.

precedents.case_name: Ma Ain Lon v. Ma On Nu
precedents.cited_proposition: Production of document on court order does not amount to 'using as genuine' under s.471 IPC

precedents.citation: In re London and Globe Finance Corp. Ltd  1903  1 ch. 728

anchor.surface_text: In re London and Globe Finance Corp. Ltd  1903  1 ch. 728 . There has been much dispute in recent years as to what Lord Buckley meant by the words deprived by deceit.

precedents.case_name: In re London and Globe Finance Corp. Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: Distinction between 'to deceive' (induce belief in false thing) and 'to defraud' (deprive by deceit, induce action to injury)
precedents.cited_holding: To deceive is to induce a man to believe that a thing is true which is false... To defraud is to deprive by deceit it is by deceit to induce a man to act to his injury.

precedents.citation: Welbam v. Director of Public Prosecutions 1 ... 1  1961 A.C. 103

anchor.surface_text: The House of Lords in Welbam v. Director of Public Prosecutions 1  ruled that it is number necessary that there must be an intention to cause an economic loss. The decision of the House of Lords has been criticized by the editors of Kennys Criminal Law and Russel on Crimes. 1  1961 A.C. 103.

precedents.case_name: Welham v. Director of Public Prosecutions
precedents.cited_proposition: Intent to defraud does not require intention to cause economic loss
